oracle study workshop

Database startup and shutdown

Posted by {"login"=>"Toby", "email"=>"renwei.chu@gmail.com", "display_name"=>"David", "first_name"=>"", "last_name"=>""} on September 2, 2007

 

Starting Up a Database

When starting the database, you select the state in which it starts. The following scenarios describe different stages of starting up an instance.

 

Starting the Instance (NOMOUNT)

An instance is started in the NOMOUNTstage only during database creation or the re-creation of control files.

Starting an instance includes the following tasks:

l         Reading the initialization file from $ORACLE_HOME/dbs in the following order:

-          First spfileSID.ora

-          If not found then, spfile.ora

-          If not found then, initSID.ora

Specifying the PFILEparameter with STARTUPoverrides the default behavior.

l         Allocating the SGA

l         Starting the background processes

l         Opening the alertSID.logfile and the trace files

 

Mounting the Database (MOUNT)

To perform specific maintenance operations, you start an instance and mount a database but do not open the database.

For example, the database must be mounted but not open during the following tasks:

l         Renaming data files (data files for an offline tablespace can berenamed when the database is open)

l         Enabling and disabling online redo log file archiving options

l         Performing full database recovery

Mounting a database includes the following tasks:

l         Associating a database with a previously started instance

l         Locating and opening the control files specified in the parameter file

l         Reading the control files to obtain the names and status of the data files and online redo log files. However, no checks are performed to verify the existence of the data files and online redo log files at this time.

 

Opening the Database (OPEN)

Normal database operation means that an instance is started and the database is mounted and open. With normal database operation, any valid user can connect to the database and perform typical data access operations.

Opening the database includes the following tasks:

l         Opening the online data files

l         Opening the online redo log files

If any of the data files or online redo log files are not present when you attempt to open the database, the Oracle server returns an error.

During this final stage, the Oracle server verifies that all thedata files and online redo log files can be opened and checks the consistency of the database. If necessary, the SMON background process initiates instance recovery.

 

SHUTDOWN Options

 
SHUTDOWN NORMAL

Normal is the default shutdown mode. Normal database shutdown proceeds with the following conditions:

l         No new connections can be made.

l         The Oracle server waits for all users to disconnect before completing the shutdown.

l         Database and redo buffers are written to disk.

l         Background processes are terminated, and the SGA is removed frommemory.

l         Oracle closes and dismounts the database before shutting down the instance.

l         The next startup does not require an instance recovery.

 

SHUTDOWN TRANSACTIONAL

A transactional shutdown prevents clients from losing work. A transactional database shutdown proceeds with the following conditions:

l         No client can start a new transaction on this particular instance.

l         A client is disconnected when the client ends the transaction that is in progress.

l         When all transactions have finished, a shutdown occurs immediately.

l         The next startup does not require an instance recovery.

 

SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATE

Immediate database shutdown proceeds with the following conditions:

l         Current SQL statements being processed by Oracle are not completed.

l         The Oracle server does not wait for the users, who are currentlyconnected to the database, to disconnect.

l         Oracle rolls back active transactions and disconnects all connected users.

l         Oracle closes and dismounts the database before shutting down the instance.

l         The next startup does not require an instance recovery.

SHUTDOWN ABORT

If the NORMALand IMMEDIATE shutdown options do not work, you can abort the current database instance. Aborting an instance proceeds with the following conditions:

l         Current SQL statements being processed by the Oracle server are immediately terminated.

l         Oracle does not wait for users currently connected to the database to disconnect.

l         Database and redo buffers are not written to disk.

l         Uncommitted transactions are not rolled back.

l         The instance is terminated without closing the files.

l         The database is not closed or dismounted.

l         The next startup requires instance recovery, which occurs automatically.

Note:It is not advisable to back up a database that is in an inconsistent state.
